item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://localhost:8882.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Bouncing Back: How Baltimore’s Heartache Sprouted Championship Glory and a Band That Wouldn’t Die
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When the Colts departed Baltimore under cover of darkness in 1984, it felt like the city lost a part of its soul. The surprise move left empty stadiums and broken promises. “30 years on, Baltimore better without Colts. The city has celebrated two Super Bowl titles with the Ravens, one more than the Indianapolis Colts have,” a retrospective reflected, capturing how the void eventually became a canvas for renewal.

From that emptiness emerged a phoenix. In 1996, Art Modell moved the Browns to Baltimore, birthing the Ravens. And for a city desperate for redemption, the timing couldn’t have been more electric. Their first Super Bowl, a crushing 34–7 win over the Giants, was validation writ large. In 2012, a second title powered by an indomitable defense, Ray Lewis’s farewell charge, and Joe Flacco’s clutch surge sealed Baltimore’s new football identity and legacy.

Through all of this storm of emotion, there was a heartbeat that never faltered: the Baltimore Colts Marching Band, famously known as “the band that would not die.” Founded in 1947, this band refused to fade when the franchise did. They marched through the city’s mourning, playing CFL games, Hall of Fame ceremonies, parades and even lobbying officials for a new stadium by performing on the steps of the Maryland State House. Former Mayor William Donald Schaefer even credited them, saying “The Colts’ band made the difference and turned the tide in winning the vote for the new stadium complex.”

Their bravest move may have been symbolic resistance. As the Colts’ moving vans rolled out, band members sneaked into the dry cleaners to retrieve their uniforms, thwarting any attempt to haul away Baltimore’s symbols to Indianapolis. That act planted them firmly in local myth.

And when the Ravens came, the band didn’t skip a beat. Initially, they wore the Colts’ uniforms and played the old fight song, a bittersweet chorus of continuity. By 1998, they had fully transformed into Baltimore’s Marching Ravens, with new purple-and-black regalia and updated music. Their journey even became the focus of the ESPN 30 for 30 documentary The Band That Wouldn’t Die.

So while the Super Bowl parades in 2000 and 2012 will always shine brightest, their power isn’t just in the trophies. It’s in the drumline of a band that refused to let Baltimore’s football spirit fall silent. The Ravens delivered the glory; the band preserved the identity. Together, they turned heartbreak into a legacy that marches on.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe title="Ravens Super Bowl Parade Seven Nation Army" width="500" height="281" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/1OmTApdO0SQ?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Orioles Magic: The Summer Baltimore Found Its Voice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On a warm June night in 1979, Memorial Stadium felt tense. The Detroit Tigers were up 5–3, the Orioles were down to their last outs, and the home crowd had started to brace for a loss. Then Ken Singleton stepped in and launched a solo home run, cutting the deficit to one. The noise rose, but the real jolt came moments later, with two outs, when Doug DeCinces connected on a pitch from Dave Tobik and sent it soaring over the fence. “Come on DeCinces: Over the fences!” the crowd had been chanting, led of course by the booming voice of Wild Bill Hagy in Section 34, and now their wish had become reality. The place exploded.

The radio call from Bill O’Donnell and Charley Eckman wasn’t polished, it was pure, joyful chaos. That’s because what happened wasn’t just a win. It was the night Orioles Magic was born. As SABR later put it, “A familiar chant from superfan Wild Bill Hagy’s roost… mingled with anxious cheering” until DeCinces’s swing lit the fuse.

The very next day, Baltimore’s new radio flagship, WFBR started shaping that feeling into something lasting. They worked up a jingle that sounded like summer baseball distilled into 30 seconds: “Every game there’s a different star… you never know who’s gonna hear the call…” It was catchy, a little cheesy, and completely infectious. “Once it debuted in 1980,” a retrospective noted, “‘Orioles Magic’ hit it out of the ballpark, quickly becoming the go-to tune adopted by generations of O’s fans.” You can still hear that original jingle today and feel the same pulse of anticipation it carried more than 40 years ago.

And at the center of that rally stood Wild Bill Hagy, a Dundalk cab driver with an unruly beard, cowboy hat, and a knack for turning a baseball crowd into a single, roaring organism. From his perch in Section 34, he’d use his body to spell out O-R-I-O-L-E-S, one letter at a time, arms and legs jutting into the air, drawing thousands into the chant. His trademark “O!” shout during the national anthem became a fixture, echoing not just through Memorial Stadium but even during spring training in Sarasota. For many fans, Hagy was Orioles Magic in human form.

Before that summer, the Orioles were good, sometimes great, but fan turnout lagged. In 1978, attendance barely scraped past one million. Then came that walk-off, the jingle, the cheers. By the end of ’79, more than 1.6 million fans had poured through the gates, shattering the franchise record. As one historian noted, “More than 1.6 million fans spun through the turnstiles that year in ’79, shattering the franchise record.” And it didn’t stop. By 1983, Baltimore drew over two million for the first time, riding that same current of energy all the way to a World Series championship.

It wasn’t just about the wins, it was about the culture. Orioles Magic reshaped Baltimore’s ballpark experience from something you watched into something you participated in. The stands became a place to shout yourself hoarse, to high-five strangers, to belt out “O!” in the anthem without worrying if it was proper. As one fan put it decades later on Reddit, “Orioles Magic—a song, a mantra, a way of life—believes there is something special about this team.”

That belief survived lean years, 14-season playoff droughts, and roster overhauls. It lived through Cal Ripken Jr.’s streak, the opening of Camden Yards, and surprise playoff runs. And it still lives today. When the jingle plays over the speakers, there’s a twitch in the chest, a ripple in the crowd. The song, the cheer, the wild man in Section 34, they’re all reminders of a summer when Baltimore didn’t just watch its team. It found its voice.
